value.0:
Carefully laid out in this tighly bound book, you find a complete calendar based on the cycles of the three moons.  Each section begins with the name of a month, followed by it's traditional meaning.

Maghieden:  The birthing moon, the time of beginnings.  Upon this first season of the druidic calenday, it is an auspicious time to begin a long journey. (Late October - Early November)

Oveanh:  The sleeping moon, this is a time for thought and contemplation.  (November)

Hunlidh:  The dreaming moon, this is a time for rest and relaxation.  (December)

Llianth:  The poet's moon, this is a time for peace, creativity, and inspiration.  (January)

Carmoil:  The waking moon, this is a time for dancing and challenging authority.  The festival of Imbolc occurs during this phase.  (February)

Haemgild:  The planting moon, this is a time for growth and emergence; an excellent time to study and practice the craft.  (March)

Gidhet:  The flower moon, this is a time for carving and craftsmanship.  (April)

Duharkat:  The cattle moon, this is a time for celebration, party, and offensive action.  Druids will oft raid the pens of livestock and set them free during this time.  (May)

Rodlima:  The bird moon, this is a time for birth, or rebirth.  (June)

Bemgusith:  The battle moon, this is a time for war and battle.  (July)

Culendom:  The harvest moon, this is a time to reap the good grace of nature, and celebrate in it's fruition.  The harvent festival of Lughnasadh is celebrated during this phase.  (August)

Alverci:  The raining moon, this is the time of storms to come and cleanse the land of all impurities.  (September)

Shar'tanog:  The dying moon, this is a time of sleep, endings, and death.  It is said all druids die during Shar'tanog, and no other time.  (Late September - Early October)

Samhain: The end of the druidic lunar year, just before the leaves turn (Early-Mid October).
  
Uenicar: A time between years; five days of chaos and change where the old year settles before the new begins.
